resources.string: \ Sample about text. Needs to be updated…

1. The valid word beep sound 'dictionary_beep.mp3' has been downloaded from following online rersource:
 http://soundbible.com/1682-Robot-Blip.html 

 2. The approach to use BloomFilter encoding to compress the wordlist and then perform a quick lookup was sugested to me by Zhongjie Mao. 

 3. For my BloomFilter implementation, I have referred to Wikipedia and the following implementation on Github:
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bloom_filter
 https://github.com/magnuss/java-bloomfilter
 
 4. For the compressed file conversion to and from byte array, I referred to following online rersources:
 http://www.exampledepot.8waytrips.com/egs/java.util/Bits2Array.html
 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6197411/converting-from-bitset-to-byte-array

1. The basic structure of this game is based on 'Letris 2' game on Android.

 2. Sudoku game in 'Hello Android' book has been used as a reference for 2D graphics, storing state and other game settings.

 3. The sounds 'button_press', 'wordgame_bg_music' and 'wordgame_menu_music' used in the game are referenced from 'www.SoundJay.com'.

 4. The sounds 'count_down', 'game_over_gong', 'valid_word_beep' and 'invalid_word_beep' used in the gme are referenced from 'www.SoundBible.com'.

 5. Android tutorials from 'www.lynda.com' were also very helpful for this assignment.

1. The game starts with the bottom row pre-populated with letters.

 2. A new letter appears on the screen at regular time intervals depending on the difficulty level.

 3. User has to click/tap on individual letters to form a word in that sequence, which is shown below the board of letters.

 4. If the word formed by the user is valid, the word turns green. User should click/tap this word to confirm it.
 This will increase the score by that words length and the corresponding letters will disappear from the board.

 5.If the word formed by the user is invalid, the word turns red. User should click/tap the 'Clear' button to clear the selection of letters.

 6. User needs to complete as many valid words as possible before the board is completely filled with letters.

 7. The number of points earned for each valid word is equal to the length of that word. 
 At the end of game, users can see their total score, longest word's length and accuracy.

 8. User can change the difficulty level, no. of rows and no. of columns from the settings button shown on the menu screen.

 9. User can pause or resume the game at any moment using the 'Pause'/'Resume' button.

 10. When the board is close to getting completely filled, users can hear a count down sound to notify them about the last few seconds remaining.

1. Never settle for one word. Almost every word on your game board can be added to. For example, the word AGE can be turned into AGED by adding a D. 

 2. It is worth waiting for a four letter scoring opportunity to come up rather than zooming through the level with three letter words and blitzing the objectives.

 3. When time is running out, quickly complete as many 3 letter words as possible.
No of rows on the board
No of cols on the board
Enter key and value to store on cloud

Following is the list of online resources referred:
 
 1. Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) 
 http://developer.android.com/google/gcm/index.html 
 
 1. Making HTTP post call: 
 http://www.mkyong.com/java/how-to-send-http-request-getpost-in-java/ 
 
 2. Setting up a broadcast receiver: 
 http://www.androidsnippets.com/how-to-set-up-a-broadcastreceiver-intent 
 
 3. Checking if activity is currently active: 
 http://androidblog.reindustries.com/check-if-an-android-activity-is-currently-running/ 
 
 4. Intent flags while launching activity: 
 http://blog.akquinet.de/2010/04/15/android-activites-and-tasks-series-intent-flags/ 
 
 5. Checking if internet is available: 
 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8573176/internet-connection-error

Every game will have 5 rounds (turn by turn), where in every turn each player gets 30 secs to make as many words as possible. 
Each word will fetch user points depending on length of that word. 
At the end of 5 rounds, the scores of all rounds will be added and the player having greater score will be the winner.

 1. User can find the opponent using the specific username or connect to a random opponent. 

 2. Connecting to a random opponent can also be done by shaking the phone. 

 3. The game starts with the bottom row pre-populated with letters.

 4. A new letter appears on the screen at regular time intervals depending on the difficulty level.

 5. User has to click/tap on individual letters to form a word in that sequence, which is shown below the board of letters.

 6. If the word formed by the user is valid, the word turns green. User should click/tap this word to confirm it.
 This will increase the score by that words length and the corresponding letters will disappear from the board.

 7.If the word formed by the user is invalid, the word turns red. User should click/tap the 'Clear' button to clear the selection of letters.

 8. User needs to complete as many valid words as possible before the timer runs out or the board is completely filled with letters.

 9. The number of points earned for each valid word is equal to the length of that word. 
 At the end of each round, users can see their total score for that round.

 10. User can pause or resume the game at any moment using the 'Pause'/'Resume' button.

 11. When the board is close to getting completely filled, users can hear a count down sound to notify them about the last few seconds remaining.

Following is the list of online resources referred:
 
 1. Google Cloud Messaging (GCM)

 1. Making HTTP post call:

 2. Setting up a broadcast receiver:

 3. Checking if activity is currently active:

 4. Intent flags while launching activity:

 6. Detecting shake using an accelerometer:

\ Sudoku is a logic-based number placement puzzle. Starting with a partially completed 9x9 grid, the objective is to fill the grid so that each row, each column, and each of the 3x3 boxes (also called blocks) contains the digits 1 to 9 exactly once.
